content.description:
In prokaryotes, the genes of the <math alttext="t r p" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">trp</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> operon encode enzymes used in the synthesis of tryptophan. The genes of the <math alttext="t r p" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">trp</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> operon are actively expressed (Figure 1A) unless abundant tryptophan is present in the environment. When tryptophan is abundant, some tryptophan binds to the <math alttext="t r p" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">trp</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> repressor protein, which in turn causes the repressor to bind to the operator and block transcription of the genes (Figure 1B). The repressor protein is encoded by the <math alttext="t r p uppercase R" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">trpR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene which is not a part of the <math alttext="t r p" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">trp</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> operon.

Figure 1A. When tryptophan is absent, the <math alttext="t r p" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">trp</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> operon is active.

Figure 1B. When tryptophan is abundant, the <math alttext="t r p" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">trp</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> operon is inactivated by the binding of the repressor protein to the operator.
content.question:
Attenuation is another mechanism by which tryptophan synthesis is regulated when tryptophan is abundant in the environment. During attenuation, ribosomes quickly translate the <math alttext="5 prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>â€²</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> end of the mRNA transcript, causing the transcript to fold into a loop that forces RNA polymerase to detach from the DNA.

Which of the following best explains why attenuation is a mechanism that is unique to prokaryotes?

choices.label: Prokaryotic genes do not contain introns.
Only prokaryotes can translate an mRNA while the mRNA is being transcribed.
Eukaryotes require more amino acids than prokaryotes do and therefore do not shut down production of tryptophan.
Eukaryotes do not have groups of genes that are regulated together.

content.answer: Only prokaryotes can translate an mRNA while the mRNA is being transcribed.
